i just want to say, for the record, that cap'n crunch's peanut butter crunch cereal is the greatest cereal ever made. everything about it is awesome including it's crunchiness, taste, overall ability to float, and of course the cap'n. to me cap'n crunch is a distinguished admiral from the british fleet circa 1820. at some point along the line he realized that sailing for king and country just to promote imperialistic tyranny was something he could no longer do, so he gave the charge of the ship to his first lieutenant george smallueson and dove off the stern somewhere in the atlantic approximately 27 miles off the coast of georgia. with regret in his heart the cap'n only thought at first of the long plunge to davey lones' locker, but the waters awoke him and with wide eyes and a growing fear he watched his ship sail east into the night. now, the cap'n was a strong-willed man, and a man of unrivaled precision. by the light and direction of the night stars he swam due west to what is now st. simons island georgia. the cap'n had no money, no shelter, no companions, no vessel, and most of all, after swimming nearly thirty miles through the night, sitting on a beach thousands of miles from his home, the cap'n was without breakfast. i would like to tell you the the good cap'n discovered or even made his famous cereal that very morning. i would even settle to tell you he eventually opened a general store where he made his delicious treat available to the public for the first time. the truth is, however, that none of those things ever really happened. cap'n crunch was hung as a traitor later that spring when he realized he was a fish out of water and went to a british outpost in canada to seek the king's mercy. it was in passing through pennsylvania that the cap'ns story was forged into legend. there he met, and enjoyed for a night the good graces of a quaker family. he was passing through to canada, a weary traveler with nothing but the delicious peanut brittle snacks he had been carrying since georgia. it was in sharing a snack and a tale of remorse to which he was seeking redemption with a small quaker child that the cap'n unwittingly formed the first cartoon cereal character for what would eventually become the quaker oat company.

i prefer things which are judged objectively. for example in swimming whoever touches the wall first wins the race (of course athletes can cheat or in the case of electronic photo finishes, machines can malfunction.) in contrast to this is subjectively judged events. an example would be gymnastics where many judges score the athletes doing different routines which have different values of scores all at different levels of proficiency (all of which are seemingly astronomically difficult.) assuming no cheating or malfunctions: events which can be judged objectively have less room for error than events which are judged subjectively. these events are superior. i also like objectivity in my life. it is there, i just have to look for it sometimes.

you might as well know i am a bit of a baseball fan. i really love the rich history of the game. i love that there are records standing which might never be broken. i was driving through chicago on sunday and i almost pulled off to try to buy scalped tickets to the cubs game. greg maddux was pitching and he has 299 career wins as a pitcher. the 300 win plateau is rare indeed in this modern age of hitting dominance and pitchers who begin to whine after five or six innings about throwing too much. 300 wins rare indeed, consider there is only one active pitcher, roger clemens, with over 300 wins right now. the rocket is at 310. the great nolan ryan pitched in 807 games over 27 seasons to reach 324. so 300 is a big deal right? consider this: cy young lost more games than maddux or clemens have won. wait, wait, wait, you might say, i thought cy young was the guy who that the best pitcher in the leagues wins an award named after him. true enough. cy young won no less than 511 games. young pitched for 22 years and he threw in an astonishing 906 games. you think that is impressive, he threw 749 complete games. that is to say he started the game and threw every pitch for his team through nine innings 749 times. the highest complete game count among active pitchers is 117 games held by clemens ( an impressive 331st best all time in mlb history!) the difference? i think it is toughness. maybe the mound is lower. maybe the hitters are bigger and stronger and faster. maybe pitchers are just whiners these days. maybe old school pitchers were just helluva tough. who knows. it is interesting though to look at the question: is 300 wins a big deal? no one will ever win 511 games and cy young's record will never be significantly challenged. but 300 wins might never happen again in my lifetime either. consider the next active pitcher on the list behind maddux is his former teammate tom glavine with 251 wins. glavine has been pitching for 17 big league seasons. he isn't likely to reach 300. after glavine there is: randy johnson 230; david wells 200; and mike mussina with 199. all of these guys are in their late thirties and have been pitching a long, long time. so what about the young guys: pedro martinez? andy pettitte? freddie garcia? c.c. sabbathia? none of them are locks and most of them aren't on pace for 300. so, this saturday watch the cubbies play the giants on fox and cheer for greg maddux as he goes for number 300 and a experience a bit of baseball history.

thursday afternoon i hit the road with the first stop being copley, oh. oh yeah, copley is a small town just north of akron, the rubber capital of the world. i hung out with kevin and maryellen and their new puppy haley. we had a good time and it was cool to get to see their house most of the way moved-into. kev bought this crazy little inflatable rowboat and i almost sunk it in his pond. i headed out early the next morning to: holland, michigan to visit my brother. holland is in southwestern michigan right on the lake. it is one of the most beautiful cities i have ever been in. flowers adorn everything and there ae parks and little gardens everywhere. the beaches on the eastern shores of lake michigan are breathtaking. the main street/ downtown area is awesome. tons of little shops and interesting things to walk and see. the suburbs, where we ventured to redeem my applebee's gift certificate (thanks, k.& m.e.!) were bizarre at best. the best i could describe it is anytown usa circa 1988. it was a little bit of a twilight zone experience. after dinner we strolled to the new holland brewing company's brew pub to sample their wares. the ipa and american ale were downright good. the stout was acceptable. the single-malt was mediocre. we woke up early the next morning and got breakfast at a local breakfast bistro downtown. let me introduce to you... the hash brown omelet. first let me say that this was hands down the geatest omelet i had ever encountered. it spun the traditional sausage, green pepper, onion, and cheese omlet with hashbrowns on the side all around to form it's greatness. get this... the eggs and other ingredients were fried inside of a delicious hashbrown casing. mmmm hashbrowns.... served with two giant slices of homemade whole wheat toast this breakfast demanded all my effort to finish. after breakfast i hit the road once again en route for: milwaukee, wi to visit bj and amber. milwaukee is kind of a weird city. it reminds me of a lot of different places including: columbus, pittsburgh, youngstown, and sharon pa. the only problem is it's parts don't fit together quite right. bj and amber gave me the official tour and it was fun. a clear highlight was leon's frozen custard. mind you, i am always extremely sceptical whenever anything is the self proclaimed "greatest_______ in the world." leon's however is truly the greatest frozen custard in the world. i would drive there just to get some more... well, maybe not but if i ever visit the mauser's or milwaukee again it is definately on the agenda. we chilled out and bj made us chicken kung-pow and we watched a knights tale. it was a very fun trip. today i drove home, laughed, cried, screamed, accidentally urinated on myself, listened to two baseball games and finally blogged before i am about to crash...
